msContents.summary: Anthology of early modern poetry arranged by image (maʿnī), compiled by the poet Banda ʿAlī Khān Bāsitī (alive in 1160 A.H.). A table of the poets featured in the anthology is given on ff.4a-9a. [JW, 2017].

msItem.title: Taz̲kirat al-shuʻarā'
تذکرة الشعراء
msItem.incipit: حمد و سپاس مرآن واجب الوجودی را که قلم دو زبان از تحریر اوصاف باکمالش حیران و سرگردان و هزاران هزار تحیت و صلوات آن در دریا رسالت تاجدار مرکز طریقت اختر برج نبوت که هر درج فتوت احمد مجتبی محمد مصطفی صلی الله علیه و سلم
msItem.explicit: تمت تمام شد تذکره لمولفه باسطی نوشته بماند سیه بر سفید نوسینده را نیست فردا امید

supportDesc.support: Throughout the manuscript, the text block is either left untinted, or is tinted in yellow or pink

layout.p: ff. 11b-17b follow a chalipa layout (each panel contains two verses written in four diagonal lines). Two columns from 17b on. Number of lines varies

handNote.desc: Copied in a neat Nasta'liq. Black ink. Red ink used to mark chapter headings and names of poets.
handNote.persName: Possibly an autograph in the hand of Banda ʿAlī Khān Bāsitī.

list.item: Front inside cover A printed note is pasted in: "197 Tezkireh as Shoara, Elegant Extracts from a numerous list of Ancient and Modern Persian Authors, Persian, very neatly written on variously tinted paper, 4to, in the original embossed gilt Persian binding, 3l. 3s. This volume is rarely to be met with in this country, and highly esteemed in the East".
Inside Covers Various notes in pen and pencil relating to former ownership and transfer: "No. 15. Elegant Extracts", "S.2657", "£3.3", "5/27", "6/6/0".

bindingDesc.p: Original binding. Leather on pasteboard. Embossed with floral and figural designs and gilded.

provenance.p: The marks of ownership and sale appear to correspond to those found in other manuscripts formerly belonging to Samuel Guise (1751-1811), most of which went to the Bland collection via Samuel Hawtayne Lewin (d 1840) and John Haddon Hindley (1765-1827). See Ursula Sims-Williams, 'The Strange Story of Samuel Guise: An 18th-Century Collection of Zoroastrian Manuscripts', Bulletin of the Asia Institute, New Series, Vol. 19, (2005), pp. 199-209.
Item 4452 in A supplement to Howell and Stewart’s Catalogue of Oriental and Oriento-Biblical Literature for 1827 , priced £3 3s.

John Wilks (d 1854). Lot 2657 in the 1847 sale, where it was sold to Bohn for £1 1s. See Sotheby, Catalogue of the valuable library of an eminent collector [John Wilks]... March 12th, 1847, and ten following days and Schoenberg SDBM_98926.

Formerly part of the collection of the Persian scholar Nathaniel Bland (1803-1865). Bland’s oriental manuscripts were sold through Bernard Quaritch in 1866 to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford.

acquisition.p: Purchased by Mrs Enriqueta Rylands, on behalf of the John Rylands Library, in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993. Identification of provenance based on manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s. Revised and expanded by James White with reference to the manuscript 2017.

availability.p: The mansucript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
